author: Amie Gordon For Mailonline
title: Alex Lester's wife blasts BBC bosses for axing husband
text:
The wife of veteran Radio 2 broadcaster Alex Lester has criticised the BBC after it axed his show - and failed to thank him after three decades of hosting The After Midnight show.
The 60-year-old, whose show was axed this month after 30 years, has now signed up for a weekly show on BBC Radio Kent.
In a scathing message on Facebook, his wife said: 'No-one in Radio 2's management team has seen fit to offer even the smallest word of thanks'.
Alex Lester, whose show was axed this month after 30 years, has now signed up for a weekly show on BBC Radio Kent
The After Midnight show was broadcast from 12am to 3am and presented by Janice Long and Alex Lester.
The BBC scrapped overnight shows hosted by the hosts, who have more than 60 years of BBC presenting experience between them.
Their programmes have been replaced by pre-recorded playlists in an apparent effort to save money.
In her Facebook post ahead of his last show, Lester's Quote: : 'No-one in Radio 2's management team has seen fit to offer even the smallest word of thanks to Alex for 30 years of making BBC Radio 2 distinctive, informative, and entertaining during the hours of the night, albeit when none of them were awake, or bothered enough, to notice.
'You'd have thought that someone in management might have invited Alex for a farewell drink, popped in to the studio to shake his hand, or, at the very least, dropped him a quick email to say thank you for everything he has done for the station for three decades.'
Lewis Carnie, Head of BBC Radio 2, said in a statement this month: 'Radio 2 has had to make extremely tough decisions to reduce programming costs in order to make savings in line with the rest of the BBC.
'As a relatively small percentage of our audience listens to Radio 2 through the night, changes need to be made to ensure that our programming spend reaches the most listeners.
'I'd like to thank both Janice Long and Alex Lester for their contributions to the programme.'
But the veteran DJ is not the first longstanding Radio 2 presenter to have been axed in recent weeks.
In a scathing message on Facebook, Lester's wife said: 'No-one in Radio 2's management team has seen fit to offer even the smallest word of thanks'
Radio 2 fans threatened to boycott the station over the way it axed veteran DJ Brian Matthew.
The BBC ousted the 88-year old Sound of the 60s presenter while he was off work recovering from a fall.
But it is now under pressure to reverse the decision, after a deluge of complaints from listeners.
They have accused the BBC of 'pure ageism' towards Mr Matthew, who joined the broadcaster in 1954 and has presented the Saturday morning show for more than a quarter of a century.
And they have lamented the loss of the DJ's 'mellow, unmistakable' voice on the airwaves, discussing sixties music as if 'from memory' rather than from a script.
The BBC said on Friday that it had mutually 'agreed' that Mr Matthew needed to 'step off the weekly treadmill of presenting the show' following a bout of ill health.
